Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Root Induced Changes of Soil Physical Properties Using Synchrotron X-ray Microtomography (CMT) and Micromechanical Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The rhizosphere, the zone of soil immediately surrounding plant roots, plays a prominent role in supplying plants with water and nutrients. However, surprisingly little is known about rhizosphere physical properties and how they affect root growth, water and nutrient uptake. The lack of non-invasive and non-destructive imaging techniques necessary to observe living roots growing in undisturbed soil have been a main reason for this shortcoming. Recent advances in synchrotron X-ray microtomography, or CMT, provide the potential to directly observe soil physical properties around living roots in-situ. The goal of this research is to quantify rhizosphere physical properties by (1) employing CMT to visualize physical root-soil structure interactions, (2) using computer models to simulate root-induced structural alterations to the rhizosphere using micro-mechanical approaches, and (3) estimating changes in rhizosphere hydraulic properties, such as water retention and hydraulic conductivity, based on CMT imaging and inverse modeling.

This research seeks to provide transformative insights into the role of rhizosphere physical properties for water and nutrient uptake by living plants. It serves as a stepping stone for better understanding the role of plants in the critical zone at the soil-atmosphere interface. The project cuts across disciplinary boundaries of biology, soil physics, and soil mechanics to offer new insights on surface runoff, soil compaction and erosion, losses to agricultural productivity, land reclamation, and principles of soil-plant interactions. Doctoral students and a post-Doctoral associate will be trained through this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied how growing plant roots compress the surrounding soil, the so-called rhizosphere, and how this compression affects the way water and nutrients flow from the soil to the root surface. This exchange is important since root-induced deformation can improve a plant’s access to water and nutrients and, therefore, plant health and growth. Using a powerful imaging system (synchrotron X-ray microtomography; CMT) that uses x-rays to create cross-sections of three-dimensional objects in the micrometer range, we could “see” the effects of plant root growth on rhizosphere structure without destroying the soil or disturbing the plant. The CMT images showed how roots establish a functional space by deforming the immediate, surrounding soil. With the help of computer simulations, we demonstrated how the soil compresses around a growing root. The simulations also showed how this interaction changes water flow from the soil to the root surface. Our results show that for loose, aggregated soils, root-induced compaction is advantageous to the plant. Specifically, root growth in a radial pattern improves contact between the root and surrounding soil, building hydraulic bridges between root and soil. Root-induced deformation also forms new and expands current contacts between aggregates, leading to better hydraulic connections between root and soil, thereby improving plant access to water and nutrients. This study provides an answer to the long-standing question: “Why do plant roots compact the surrounding soil if compaction is detrimental for water and nutrient uptake?” The study also serves as a stepping stone toward better understanding of how roots physically alter their environment. By cutting across disciplinary boundaries, this project provided new insights into first-principles of soil-plant interactions.
